metaphor.core: The layered dream worlds from 'Inception', meticulously designed by an architect and connected through shared ideas and synchronized 'kicks', serve as a powerful metaphor for React component architecture. Each dream layer represents an isolated, reusable component, props are the 'ideas' passed between them, and synchronized 'kicks' illustrate callback functions for inter-component communication.

mapping.reactConcept: An isolated, reusable React component with its own internal state and logic.
The React developer, responsible for designing and composing components.
The React renderer, bringing components to life on the screen.
The principle of component isolation: components manage their own concerns and do not directly interfere with others.

mapping.fictionElement: Monolithic blueprint where everything bleeds into everything else
mapping.reactConcept: An anti-pattern: a single, large component (or deeply interconnected components without clear boundaries) where state changes cause unpredictable side effects across the entire application.

mapping.fictionElement: A stack of maps, each with its own rules
mapping.reactConcept: Breaking down a complex UI into a hierarchical structure of smaller, specialized components.

mapping.fictionElement: Ideas passed down between dream layers (e.g., Fischer's father's idea)
mapping.reactConcept: Props: data passed from a parent component to a child component, defining its interface and behavior.
Callback functions: passed as props from parent to child, allowing child components to communicate events or data back up to their parents, enabling coordinated actions.

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module takes us through Ariadne's journey from designing a single isolated dream (component isolation), to witnessing the chaos of a monolithic blueprint (anti-pattern of entangled state), to her epiphany of creating a 'stack of maps' (component composition with clear interfaces). It then contrasts the monolithic vs. component-based approach and culminates in the 'synchronized kick' to demonstrate elegant inter-component communication through props and callbacks.

problems: Monolithic components leading to unpredictable state changes and debugging difficulties
State leakage between unrelated parts of the UI
Difficulty in managing complex UIs without clear boundaries
Inefficient updates due to entangled state.

chapters.title: The Parisian Cafe
chapters.focus: Introduces the concept of React components as isolated, reusable units with defined boundaries and internal state.

chapters.title: The Monolithic Blueprint
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the anti-pattern of a single, massive component with entangled state, leading to unpredictable side effects and debugging challenges.

chapters.title: A Stack of Maps
chapters.focus: Explains the solution: breaking down complex UIs into isolated, composable components with clear `props` interfaces.

chapters.title: The Monolith vs. The Stack
chapters.focus: Compares the behavior and maintainability of monolithic components versus a well-composed component stack, highlighting predictability through isolation.

chapters.title: The Synchronized Kick
chapters.focus: Illustrates how callback functions (passed as props) enable elegant and coordinated inter-component communication for complex application logic.

interactiveElements: Interactive 'Parisian Cafe' component demonstrating internal state management and isolation
Simulating monolithic state chaos with unintended side effects across virtual 'dream layers'
Visualizing a 'component stack' with distinct, isolated layers communicating via props
Side-by-side comparison of monolithic vs. composed architecture behavior
Triggering a 'synchronized kick' cascade through nested components using callback props
